title: Food crime reports rise to highest level since horse meat scandal
text:
There were almost 7,000 reports of food crime between January 2013 and the end of March this year, according to data revealed by the National Food Crime Unit in response to a freedom of information request by the Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply (CIPS).

Of these, 1,193 were made in 2018, the highest level since 2013 when the horse meat scandal struck. That year, 1,517 complaints were logged.

Mr Lang said: “There’s a financial incentive to use substandard food. What we’re seeing here is a new, more sophisticated crime occuring and being normalised. It’s the normalisation of this crime, which is the worrying thing.

“If you have a beyond the sell by date or a meat that is going off and you cut out the bad bits and just put the rest of it through the mincer, you’ve got an opportunity to add value to something that otherwise is worthless.”

The crime reports often relate to chemicals included in food supplements.

For example, these could include DNP, a toxic chemical which is sometimes sold as a weight-loss aid, or a so-called magic mineral solution, which has a range of alleged health benefits but is unsafe for human consumption.

The hike in complaints could be partly because a greater number of these products are sold online, making them easier to get hold of.

Other criminal cases could involve using products different from what is claimed on packaging.

There have been 364 calls relating to mislabelling products or replacing some ingredients for cheaper alternatives among other concerns, in the first three months of 2019 alone.

For example, one industry source said that to make black pudding, some grocers import blood from eastern Europe and dilute it with water in Britain, before turning it into a breakfast item which they say is “produced in the UK”.

Malcolm Harrison, the boss of the CIPS, said: “Businesses must ensure that supply chains are transparent and that goods can be tracked from their source. It is important to visit suppliers and introduce regular quality and compliance checks to ensure sound international supply chain practices.”

Tesco came under fire three years ago for coming up with fictional British-sounding farm names, such as Boswell Farms and Rosedene Farms, on its cheaper ranges of fresh produce, some of which were sourced from abroad.

Waitrose also had to rebrand some of its “British” range ready meals because a proportion were made with New Zealand lamb.

Reports, however, are not automatically offences and multiple complaints may be received for one incident.

Darren Davies, the head of the National Food Crime Unit, said: “We work to protect consumers from criminal conduct. We would encourage anyone who believes they have knowledge of food fraud being committed to contact us.”

Some food producers are up in arms about prospective trade deals with the likes of the US and Australia, which by opening up competition to larger, cheaper producers could dent profits and lower the standards, they argue.
description: Food unfit for human consumption is increasingly making its way onto the shelves of shops as a wave of mislabelled products enters the supply chain.
